content.question: A polar curve is given by the equation <math alttext="r equals, the fraction with numerator 10 theta, and denominator theta squared, plus 1, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="theta greater than or equal to 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>θ</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. What is the instantaneous rate of change of <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with respect to <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> when <math alttext="theta equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

unit.text: 9: Parametric Equations, Polar Coordinates, and Vector-Valued Functions

topic.text: 9.7: (BC ONLY) Defining Polar Coordinates and Differentiating in Polar Form

skill.text: Skill 2.D: Identify how mathematical characteristics or properties of functions are related in different representations.
